Workflow

In this part, we will show you all the steps we did to obtain all our final results including susceptibility map and exposure assessment.

Step1 Data Preprocessing

For all the origin data, we clip all of them considering only the region of interest and we checked that the pixel size and CRS of all layers were coherent.

Basic Data

Computed Data From DTM

Landslide Zone and Non Landslide Zone

We used the landslide inventory to define the landslide zone. And for non landslide zone, We defined this areas as the slopes with angle smaller then 20° or grater then 70° using the raster calculator. Because of some overlappings between LZ and NLZ, we remove all the overlapping parts from the NLZ. And because there were too many small patches of pixels, we removed them with a threshold of 25. Thereby, we obtain the final LZ and NLZ.

Then, we split both zones into training dataset and testing dataset with a ration of 70%/30%. For futher operations, we merged 2 layer into 1 layer and randomly selected 1000 points(350 points/150 points from each of the two layers to form the training/testing set respectively.) in total inside the polygons.

Train_Test Hazard Number of Points
Training 1(NLZ) 350
Training 2(LZ) 350
Testing 1(NLZ) 150
Testing 2()LZ 150

Step2 Susceptibility Map Generation

For the generation of the susceptibility map we use Dzetsaka plugin in QGIS with random forest. To generate the susceptibility map, we used raster calculator to convert classification and confidence to probability. Then we validated the accuracy of the our output using python script.

Step3 Data preprocessing for exposure assessment

To analyze the exposure assessment we downloaded the population raster dataset (WorldPop map) and we reprojected the population raster dataset using the same CRS of layers obtained in the previous steps. We reclassified the susceptibility raster map to 4 classes:

Probability Class
[0,25) Low
[25,50) Moderate
[50,75) High
[75,100] Very High

Step4 Exposure Assessment

For the last step, we used QGIS Raster layer zonal statistics tool to compute the population count in each class.
